title: PC fantasy or historically accurate? What World On Fire gets right – and wrong – about war
text:
The first clue that World On Fire might keep lovers of historical accuracy busy in the coming weeks came within minutes of the opening credits. BBC One's Second World War drama opened in 1939 with two of our heroes entering a Blackshirts rally in Manchester, addressed by Oswald Mosley, and interrupting proceedings by singing Bye Bye Blackshirts.

In reality, a group of anti-Fascists did exactly this - but the incident happened five years earlier. That’s not to say it couldn’t have happened again, but it does smack of bending history for the sake of a strong opening.

Then there's the series' fictional American reporter, based on the real-life heroine of British journalism at the time Clare Hollingworth...
